news_summary: Astronomers have made remarkable discoveries including capturing the birth of planets around a young star, identifying a mysterious object near Neptune, and uncovering an unexpected power source in a rare pulsar.
news_summary_fr: Les astronomes ont fait des découvertes remarquables, notamment en captant la naissance de planètes autour d'une jeune étoile, en identifiant un objet mystérieux près de Neptune et en découvrant une source d'énergie inattendue dans un pulsar rare.
news_summary_es: Los astrónomos han realizado descubrimientos notables, como la captación del nacimiento de planetas alrededor de una estrella joven, la identificación de un misterioso objeto cerca de Neptuno y el descubrimiento de una fuente de energía inesperada en un púlsar poco común.

articles.title: Astronomers just witnessed planets being born around a baby star 1300 light-years away
articles.summary: Astronomers have, for the first time, observed the very beginning of planet formation around a star beyond our Solar System. Using the James Webb Space Telescope and ALMA, researchers detected hot minerals starting to solidify in the dusty disc surrounding a young star called HOPS-315, located 1300 light-years from Earth. These minerals mark the earliest seeds of planets, offering a stunning parallel to how Earth and the other planets in our Solar System likely formed. This breakthrough provides a rare opportunity to watch the process of planet birth unfold in real time.
articles.content:
International researchers have, for the first time, pinpointed the moment when planets began to form around a star beyond the Sun. Using the ALMA telescope, in which the European Southern Observatory (ESO) is a partner, and the James Webb Space Telescope, they have observed the creation of the first specks of planet-forming material -- hot minerals just beginning to solidify. This finding marks the first time a planetary system has been identified at such an early stage in its formation and opens a window to the past of our own Solar System.

"For the first time, we have identified the earliest moment when planet formation is initiated around a star other than our Sun," says Melissa McClure, a professor at Leiden University in the Netherlands and lead author of the new study, published on July 16 in Nature.

Co-author Merel van 't Hoff, a professor at Purdue University, USA, compares their findings to "a picture of the baby Solar System," saying that "we're seeing a system that looks like what our Solar System looked like when it was just beginning to form."

This newborn planetary system is emerging around HOPS-315, a 'proto' or baby star that sits some 1300 light-years away from us and is an analogue of the nascent Sun. Around such baby stars, astronomers often see discs of gas and dust known as 'protoplanetary discs', which are the birthplaces of new planets. While astronomers have previously seen young discs that contain newborn, massive, Jupiter-like planets, McClure says, "we've always known that the first solid parts of planets, or 'planetesimals', must form further back in time, at earlier stages."

In our Solar System, the very first solid material to condense near Earth's present location around the Sun is found trapped within ancient meteorites. Astronomers age-date these primordial rocks to determine when the clock started on our Solar System's formation. Such meteorites are packed full of crystalline minerals that contain silicon monoxide (SiO) and can condense at the extremely high temperatures present in young planetary discs. Over time, these newly condensed solids bind together, sowing the seeds for planet formation as they gain both size and mass. The first kilometer-sized planetesimals in the Solar System, which grew to become planets such as Earth or Jupiter's core, formed just after the condensation of these crystalline minerals.

With their new discovery, astronomers have found evidence of these hot minerals beginning to condense in the disc around HOPS-315. Their results show that SiO is present around the baby star in its gaseous state, as well as within these crystalline minerals, suggesting it is only just beginning to solidify. "This process has never been seen before in a protoplanetary disc -- or anywhere outside our Solar System," says co-author Edwin Bergin, a professor at the University of Michigan, USA.

These minerals were first identified using the James Webb Space Telescope, a joint project of the US, European and Canadian space agencies. To find out where exactly the signals were coming from, the team observed the system with ALMA, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array, which is operated by ESO together with international partners in Chile's Atacama Desert.

With these data, the team determined that the chemical signals were coming from a small region of the disc around the star equivalent to the orbit of the asteroid belt around the Sun. "We're really seeing these minerals at the same location in this extrasolar system as where we see them in asteroids in the Solar System," says co-author Logan Francis, a postdoctoral researcher at Leiden University.

Because of this, the disc of HOPS-315 provides a wonderful analogue for studying our own cosmic history. As van 't Hoff says, "this system is one of the best that we know to actually probe some of the processes that happened in our Solar System." It also provides astronomers with a new opportunity to study early planet formation, by standing in as a substitute for newborn solar systems across the galaxy.

ESO astronomer and European ALMA Program Manager Elizabeth Humphreys, who did not take part in the study, says: "I was really impressed by this study, which reveals a very early stage of planet formation. It suggests that HOPS-315 can be used to understand how our own Solar System formed. This result highlights the combined strength of JWST and ALMA for exploring protoplanetary discs."

The team is composed of M. K. McClure (Leiden Observatory, Leiden University, The Netherlands [Leiden]), M. van 't Hoff (Department of Astronomy, The University of Michigan, Michigan, USA [Michigan] and Purdue University, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Indiana, USA), L. Francis (Leiden), Edwin Bergin (Michigan), W.R. M. Rocha (Leiden), J. A. Sturm (Leiden), D. Harsono (Institute of Astronomy, Department of Physics, National Tsing Hua University, Taiwan), E. F. van Dishoeck (Leiden), J. H. Black (Chalmers University of Technology, Department of Space, Earth and Environment, Onsala Space Observatory, Sweden), J. A. Noble (Physique des Interactions Ioniques et Moléculaires, CNRS, Aix Marseille Université, France), D. Qasim (Southwest Research Institute, Texas, USA), E. Dartois (Institut des Sciences Moléculaires d'Orsay, CNRS, Université Paris-Saclay, France.)
articles.reasoning: This article reports a groundbreaking scientific discovery about the earliest stages of planet formation around a baby star, providing new insights into the origins of planetary systems including our own. It highlights international collaboration, advanced technology, and expands human knowledge about the universe, which is inspiring and hopeful.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers witness planets being born around a baby star 1300 light-years away
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
For the first time ever, scientists have caught a glimpse of planets beginning to form around a young star far beyond our Solar System. This discovery shines a light on how planets, including Earth, may have come to be.

**What happened**
Using two powerful space tools—the James Webb Space Telescope and the ALMA telescope—astronomers spotted hot minerals starting to harden in a dusty disc around a baby star named HOPS-315, located 1300 light-years from Earth. These minerals are the very first building blocks of planets.

**Impact**
This breakthrough gives us a rare chance to watch planet formation in real time. It helps scientists better understand the early stages of how planetary systems develop, offering clues about the origins of our own Solar System.

**What's next step**
Researchers will continue to study young stars and their surrounding discs to learn more about how planets form and grow. Future observations with advanced telescopes will deepen our knowledge of the universe and the birth of planets.

**One-sentence takeaway**
For the first time, we’re witnessing the earliest steps of planet formation around a distant star, unlocking secrets of how worlds like ours come to life.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes assistent à la naissance de planètes autour d'une jeune étoile à 1300 années-lumière
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Pour la première fois, des scientifiques ont observé des planètes en train de se former autour d'une jeune étoile bien au-delà de notre système solaire. Cette découverte éclaire la façon dont les planètes, dont la Terre, ont pu apparaître.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Grâce à deux puissants outils spatiaux—le télescope spatial James Webb et le télescope ALMA—les astronomes ont repéré des minéraux chauds commençant à durcir dans un disque poussiéreux autour d’une étoile bébé nommée HOPS-315, à 1300 années-lumière de la Terre. Ces minéraux sont les tout premiers éléments qui forment les planètes.

**Impact**
Cette avancée nous offre une occasion rare d’observer la formation des planètes en temps réel. Elle aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre les premières étapes du développement des systèmes planétaires, donnant des indices sur les origines de notre propre système solaire.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier les jeunes étoiles et leurs disques environnants pour en apprendre davantage sur la formation et la croissance des planètes. Les futures observations avec des télescopes avancés approfondiront notre connaissance de l’univers et de la naissance des planètes.

**En une phrase**
Pour la première fois, nous assistons aux premières étapes de la formation des planètes autour d’une étoile lointaine, dévoilant les secrets de la naissance des mondes comme le nôtre.
articles.personality_title_es: Los astrónomos presencian el nacimiento de planetas alrededor de una estrella bebé a 1300 años luz
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Por primera vez, los científicos han observado planetas comenzando a formarse alrededor de una joven estrella muy lejos de nuestro Sistema Solar. Este descubrimiento nos ayuda a entender cómo pueden haberse formado planetas como la Tierra.

**Qué pasó**
Usando dos potentes herramientas espaciales—el telescopio espacial James Webb y el telescopio ALMA—los astrónomos detectaron minerales calientes empezando a solidificarse en un disco polvoriento alrededor de una estrella bebé llamada HOPS-315, a 1300 años luz de la Tierra. Estos minerales son los primeros bloques que forman planetas.

**Impacto**
Este avance nos brinda una oportunidad única para ver la formación de planetas en tiempo real. Ayuda a los científicos a comprender mejor las primeras etapas en el desarrollo de sistemas planetarios, ofreciendo pistas sobre los orígenes de nuestro propio Sistema Solar.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores seguirán estudiando estrellas jóvenes y sus discos para aprender más sobre cómo se forman y crecen los planetas. Observaciones futuras con telescopios avanzados profundizarán nuestro conocimiento del universo y el nacimiento de planetas.

**Resumen en una frase**
Por primera vez, estamos presenciando los primeros pasos de la formación de planetas alrededor de una estrella lejana, revelando secretos sobre cómo nacen mundos como el nuestro.
articles.image_prompt: A softly glowing, swirling protoplanetary disc of warm amber and gentle ochre hues encircles a bright, young star at its center, with delicate crystalline mineral specks beginning to sparkle and coalesce like tiny seeds within the dust, set against a serene cosmic backdrop of deep blues and muted purples.

articles.title: Mysterious object found dancing with Neptune
articles.summary: Astronomers have discovered a bizarre object in the outer solar system, 2020 VN40, that dances to Neptune’s gravitational beat in a never-before-seen rhythm. It’s the first of its kind, orbiting the Sun once for every ten orbits of Neptune, and could reshape how we understand the movement and evolution of distant cosmic bodies.
articles.content:
A team of astronomers led by the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian has discovered a rare object far beyond Neptune, from a class known as trans-Neptunian objects, that is moving in rhythm with the giant planet. This object, called 2020 VN40, is the first confirmed body that orbits the sun once for every ten orbits Neptune completes.

This discovery helps scientists understand how objects in the outer solar system behave and how they got there. It supports the idea that many distant objects are temporarily "caught" in Neptune's gravity as they drift through space.

"This is a big step in understanding the outer solar system," said Rosemary Pike, lead researcher from the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian. "It shows that even very distant regions influenced by Neptune can contain objects, and it gives us new clues about how the solar system evolved."

The finding was published this month in The Planetary Science Journal, a publication of the American Astronomical Society.

The discovery was made by the Large inclination Distant Objects (LiDO) survey, which searched for unusual objects in the outer solar system. This survey used the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope for the main survey operations, and Gemini Observatory and Magellan Baade for additional observations.

The survey was designed to search for bodies with orbits that extend far above and below the plane of the Earth's orbit around the sun, part of the outer solar system that hasn't been well-studied.

"It has been fascinating to learn how many small bodies in the solar system exist on these very large, very tilted orbits," said Dr. Samantha Lawler (University of Regina), a core member of the LiDO team. The object's average distance is about 140 times farther from the sun than Earth and follows a very tilted path around the solar system.

What makes 2020 VN40 even more interesting is how it moves compared to Neptune. Most objects with a simple ratio of the duration of their orbit compared to the duration of Neptune's orbit always come closest to the sun when Neptune is far away. In contrast, 2020 VN40 comes closest to the sun when Neptune is very close by, if you look at their positions from above the solar system. The tilt of 2020 VN40's orbit means that the objects are not actually close, because 2020 VN40 is actually far below the solar system- they only appear close when flattened onto a map. All other known resonant trans-Neptunian objects orbit such that they avoid this alignment at their closest approach to the sun, even in the flattened view.

"This new motion is like finding a hidden rhythm in a song we thought we knew," said Ruth Murray-Clay (University of California Santa Cruz), co-author of the study. "It could change how we think about the way distant objects move."

These findings suggest that highly tilted orbits can lead to new and unexpected types of motion. The LiDO survey has already found over 140 distant objects, and more discoveries are expected from future surveys. With telescopes like the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, scientists hope to find many more objects like 2020 VN40.

"This is just the beginning," said Kathryn Volk of the Planetary Science Institute. "We're opening a new window into the solar system's past."
articles.reasoning: The discovery of a new type of trans-Neptunian object with a unique orbital resonance to Neptune represents a significant scientific breakthrough in our understanding of the solar system's evolution. It opens new avenues for research and inspires curiosity about the cosmos, which is uplifting and hopeful for a wide audience interested in space and science.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers discover a cosmic dance partner for Neptune
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Far beyond the familiar planets lies a region filled with icy, distant objects orbiting the Sun. These trans-Neptunian objects are mysterious and help scientists learn about our solar system’s past.

**What happened**
A team of astronomers found a rare object named 2020 VN40 that orbits the Sun in a special pattern connected to Neptune. For every one orbit 2020 VN40 makes, Neptune completes ten orbits. This unique “dance” is the first of its kind ever seen.

**Impact**
This discovery gives scientists new clues about how objects far from the Sun move and interact. It helps us understand the solar system’s evolution and could change how we think about these distant cosmic bodies.

**What's next step**
Researchers will continue studying 2020 VN40 and search for more objects with similar orbits. This will deepen our understanding of the outer solar system’s dynamics and history.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A tiny object far beyond Neptune is dancing in sync with the planet, opening a new chapter in our cosmic story.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des astronomes découvrent un partenaire de danse cosmique pour Neptune
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Au-delà des planètes familières se trouve une région remplie d’objets glacés et lointains qui tournent autour du Soleil. Ces objets transneptuniens sont mystérieux et aident les scientifiques à comprendre le passé de notre système solaire.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une équipe d’astronomes a trouvé un objet rare nommé 2020 VN40 qui orbite autour du Soleil selon un motif spécial lié à Neptune. Pour chaque orbite de 2020 VN40, Neptune en effectue dix. Cette « danse » unique est une première.

**Impact**
Cette découverte offre de nouveaux indices aux scientifiques sur les mouvements et interactions des objets loin du Soleil. Elle aide à mieux comprendre l’évolution du système solaire et pourrait changer notre vision de ces corps cosmiques lointains.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier 2020 VN40 et chercher d’autres objets avec des orbites similaires. Cela approfondira notre connaissance de la dynamique et de l’histoire du système solaire extérieur.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Un petit objet au-delà de Neptune danse en rythme avec la planète, ouvrant un nouveau chapitre dans notre histoire cosmique.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos descubren un compañero de baile cósmico para Neptuno
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Más allá de los planetas conocidos hay una región llena de objetos helados y distantes que orbitan el Sol. Estos objetos transneptunianos son misteriosos y ayudan a los científicos a entender el pasado de nuestro sistema solar.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo de astrónomos encontró un objeto raro llamado 2020 VN40 que orbita el Sol en un patrón especial conectado a Neptuno. Por cada órbita que hace 2020 VN40, Neptuno completa diez. Este “baile” único es el primero de su tipo.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento brinda nuevas pistas sobre cómo se mueven e interactúan los objetos alejados del Sol. Nos ayuda a comprender la evolución del sistema solar y podría cambiar cómo vemos estos cuerpos cósmicos distantes.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores seguirán estudiando 2020 VN40 y buscando más objetos con órbitas similares. Esto profundizará nuestra comprensión de la dinámica e historia del sistema solar exterior.

**Resumen en una frase**
Un pequeño objeto más allá de Neptuno baila en sincronía con el planeta, abriendo un nuevo capítulo en nuestra historia cósmica.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a giant blue Neptune with swirling clouds, gracefully accompanied by a smaller, glowing distant celestial orb tracing a tilted, rhythmic orbit around it, both set against a softly colored cosmic backdrop sprinkled with subtle stars and abstract orbital paths illustrating their unique synchronized dance far beyond the sun.

articles.title: NASA’s IXPE tracked a rare pulsar—and found an unexpected power source
articles.summary: Astronomers studying a rare neutron star system have uncovered a surprising source of powerful X-rays. Using NASA s IXPE telescope and data from other observatories, an international team found that the radiation doesn't come from the star s surrounding disk of gas, as previously believed, but from a wild and turbulent pulsar wind. This fast-moving stream of particles and magnetic energy slams into the disk, producing the X-rays scientists detected.
articles.content:
An international team of astronomers has uncovered new evidence to explain how pulsing remnants of exploded stars interact with surrounding matter deep in the cosmos, using observations from NASA's IXPE (Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer) and other telescopes.

Scientists based in the U.S., Italy, and Spain, set their sights on a mysterious cosmic duo called PSR J1023+0038, or J1023 for short. The J1023 system is comprised of a rapidly rotating neutron star feeding off of its low-mass companion star, which has created an accretion disk around the neutron star. This neutron star is also a pulsar, emitting powerful twin beams of light from its opposing magnetic poles as it rotates, spinning like a lighthouse beacon.

The J1023 system is rare and valuable to study because the pulsar transitions clearly between its active state, in which it feeds off its companion star, and a more dormant state, when it emits detectable pulsations as radio waves. This makes it a "transitional millisecond pulsar."

"Transitional millisecond pulsars are cosmic laboratories, helping us understand how neutron stars evolve in binary systems," said researcher Maria Cristina Baglio of the Italian National Institute of Astrophysics (INAF) Brera Observatory in Merate, Italy, and lead author of a paper in The Astrophysical Journal Letters illustrating the new findings.

The big question for scientists about this pulsar system was: Where do the X-rays originate? The answer would inform broader theories about particle acceleration, accretion physics, and the environments surrounding neutron stars across the universe.

The source surprised them: The X-rays came from the pulsar wind, a chaotic stew of gases, shock waves, magnetic fields, and particles accelerated near the speed of light, that hits the accretion disk.

To determine this, astronomers needed to measure the angle of polarization in both X-ray and optical light. Polarization is a measure of how organized light waves are. They looked at X-ray polarization with IXPE, the only telescope capable of making this measurement in space, and comparing it with optical polarization from the European Southern Observatory's Very Large Telescope in Chile. IXPE launched in Dec. 2021 and has made many observations of pulsars, but J1023 was the first system of its kind that it explored.

NASA's NICER (Neutron star Interior Composition Explorer) and Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory provided valuable observations of the system in high-energy light. Other telescopes contributing data included the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array in Magdalena, New Mexico.

The result: scientists found the same angle of polarization across the different wavelengths.

"That finding is compelling evidence that a single, coherent physical mechanism underpins the light we observe," said Francesco Coti Zelati of the Institute of Space Sciences in Barcelona, Spain, co-lead author of the findings.

This interpretation challenges the conventional wisdom about neutron star emissions of radiation in binary systems, the researchers said. Previous models had indicated that the X-rays come from the accretion disk, but this new study shows they originate with the pulsar wind.

"IXPE has observed many isolated pulsars and found that the pulsar wind powers the X-rays," said NASA Marshall astrophysicist Philip Kaaret, principal investigator for IXPE at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. "These new observations show that the pulsar wind powers most of the energy output of the system."

Astronomers continue to study transitional millisecond pulsars, assessing how observed physical mechanisms compare with those of other pulsars and pulsar wind nebulae. Insights from these observations could help refine theoretical models describing how pulsar winds generate radiation - and bring researchers one step closer, Baglio and Coti Zelati agreed, to fully understanding the physical mechanisms at work in these extraordinary cosmic systems.

More about IXPE

IXPE, which continues to provide unprecedented data enabling groundbreaking discoveries about celestial objects across the universe, is a joint NASA and Italian Space Agency mission with partners and science collaborators in 12 countries. IXPE is led by NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. BAE Systems, Inc., headquartered in Falls Church, Virginia, manages spacecraft operations together with the University of Colorado's Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics in Boulder.
articles.reasoning: This article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding neutron star systems, made possible by advanced space technology and international collaboration. It expands human knowledge about the universe and showcases successful space missions and research.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s IXPE reveals surprising power source behind rare pulsar’s X-rays
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Astronomers have long been curious about how certain neutron stars, which are dense leftovers of exploded stars, produce powerful X-rays. One such system, called PSR J1023+0038, or J1023, features a fast-spinning neutron star and a small companion star. Scientists previously thought the X-rays came from a disk of gas around the neutron star.

**What happened**
Using NASA’s IXPE telescope along with other observatories, an international team discovered that the X-rays actually come from a strong, fast-moving wind of particles and magnetic energy—a pulsar wind. This wind crashes into the gas disk, creating the bursts of X-rays detected by the scientists.

**Impact**
This finding changes our understanding of how neutron stars interact with their surroundings. It highlights the power of new space technology and international teamwork in uncovering cosmic mysteries. This breakthrough helps expand our knowledge about the universe and the forces at work in extreme environments.

**What’s next step**
Scientists plan to use IXPE and other instruments to study more pulsar systems and see if similar winds are common. This will help confirm their findings and deepen our understanding of how these unusual stars behave.

**One-sentence takeaway**
NASA’s IXPE has uncovered a surprising source of powerful X-rays from a rare pulsar, showing that a wild pulsar wind—not just surrounding gas—is responsible.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA dévoile la source surprenante des rayons X d’un pulsar rare
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les astronomes s’interrogent depuis longtemps sur la façon dont certaines étoiles à neutrons, restes d’étoiles explosées, produisent des rayons X puissants. Un système appelé PSR J1023+0038, ou J1023, comprend une étoile à neutrons en rotation rapide et une petite étoile compagne. On pensait auparavant que les rayons X venaient d’un disque de gaz autour de l’étoile à neutrons.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Grâce au télescope IXPE de la NASA et à d’autres observatoires, une équipe internationale a découvert que les rayons X proviennent en réalité d’un vent puissant et rapide de particules et d’énergie magnétique, appelé vent de pulsar. Ce vent percute le disque de gaz, créant les rayons X observés.

**Impact**
Cette découverte change notre compréhension des interactions entre les étoiles à neutrons et leur environnement. Elle montre l’importance des nouvelles technologies spatiales et de la collaboration internationale pour percer les mystères cosmiques. Cette avancée enrichit nos connaissances sur l’univers et les forces en jeu dans des environnements extrêmes.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d’utiliser IXPE et d’autres instruments pour étudier d’autres systèmes de pulsars et vérifier si ces vents sont fréquents. Cela aidera à confirmer leurs découvertes et à mieux comprendre le comportement de ces étoiles particulières.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Le télescope IXPE de la NASA a révélé une source inattendue de rayons X puissants provenant d’un pulsar rare, prouvant que c’est un vent de pulsar turbulent, et non seulement le gaz environnant, qui en est responsable.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA revela la sorprendente fuente de rayos X de un púlsar raro
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los astrónomos han estado interesados en cómo ciertas estrellas de neutrones, restos densos de estrellas explotadas, generan rayos X fuertes. Un sistema llamado PSR J1023+0038, o J1023, tiene una estrella de neutrones que gira rápido y una estrella compañera pequeña. Antes se pensaba que los rayos X provenían de un disco de gas alrededor de la estrella.

**Qué pasó**
Usando el telescopio IXPE de la NASA y otros observatorios, un equipo internacional descubrió que los rayos X en realidad vienen de un viento rápido y poderoso de partículas y energía magnética, llamado viento de púlsar. Este viento choca contra el disco de gas, produciendo los rayos X detectados.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo cambia nuestra comprensión de cómo las estrellas de neutrones interactúan con su entorno. Muestra el valor de la tecnología espacial moderna y la colaboración internacional para descubrir misterios cósmicos. Este avance amplía nuestro conocimiento sobre el universo y las fuerzas en ambientes extremos.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean usar IXPE y otros instrumentos para estudiar más sistemas de púlsares y ver si estos vientos son comunes. Esto ayudará a confirmar sus hallazgos y a entender mejor el comportamiento de estas estrellas.

**Conclusión en una frase**
El IXPE de la NASA encontró una fuente inesperada de poderosos rayos X en un púlsar raro, demostrando que es un viento turbulento de púlsar, no solo el gas alrededor, el responsable.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, spinning neutron star with twin beams of light like lighthouse beacons sweeping across a swirling, translucent accretion disk, set against a calm cosmic backdrop of soft blues and gentle purples, symbolizing the pulsar wind’s powerful energy interacting with its companion star’s matter in a harmonious celestial dance.

articles.title: Daily briefing: The birth of a solar system caught ‘on camera’ for the first time
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02299-yResearchers have spotted a baby star at the beginning of its planet forming era. Plus, eight babies conceived via ‘three-person in vitro fertilization’ are living healthy lives and the best popular science and scholarly books to read now.
articles.content:
Researchers have spotted a baby star at the beginning of its planet forming era. Plus, eight babies conceived via ‘three-person in vitro fertilization’ are living healthy lives and the best popular science and scholarly books to read now.

Hello Nature readers, would you like to get this Briefing in your inbox free every day? Sign up here.

HOPS-315, as imaged by the Atacama Large Millimeter-submillimeter Array in Chile (orange is carbon monoxide blowing away from the central star, blue is silicon monoxide).Credit: ALMA(ESO/NAOJ/NRAO)/M. McClure et al.

Astronomers have spotted a solar system beyond our own in its very earliest stages of formation. Using both ground- and space-based telescopes, the team zeroed in on the young star, named HOPS-315, at the start of its planet-forming era. The baby star was at just the right orientation for astronomers to get a glimpse of its surrounding disk of gas and dust, which is usually obscured by jets of gas pumped out by newborn stars. Researchers have long sought such a system to help them understand the humble beginnings of our own.

Nature | 4 min read

Reference: Nature paper

Eight children conceived through a controversial reproductive technique called mitochondrial donation are living healthy lives. The procedure, dubbed ‘three-person in vitro fertilization’, involves transferring the nucleus of a fertilized egg that has faulty mitochondria into a donor egg with healthy ones. As a result, the children carry nuclear DNA from a biological mother and father, alongside mitochondrial DNA from a separate egg donor. The technique aims to prevent babies inheriting harmful mutations from their mother’s mitochondrial DNA, which can cause debilitating diseases that affect power-hungry tissues such as the heart and muscles.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: New England Journal of Medicine paper 1 & paper 2

Drosophila research hasn’t fallen victim to the ‘reproducibility crisis’, a new study suggests. Of more than 1,000 claims about the fruit flies’ immunity in scientific papers published over some 50 years, at least 61% are verifiable through replication. Only 7% had been challenged and proved not to be reproducible. “There is a narrative of a ‘reproducibility crisis’ in science, which sounds dramatic,” says study co-author and Drosophila researcher Mark Hanson, but adds that the scientists themselves are rarely that worried. In the field of fly genetics, “we constantly build on each other’s work”, he says.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: bioRxiv preprint 1 & preprint 2

Kimi K2, launched by Moonshot AI, is the second powerful artificial intelligence (AI) model to emerge from China, after DeepSeek shocked the world with its launch of R1 in January. Kimi K2 appears to excel at coding, scoring high in tests of code-related tasks. A big advantage of both models is that they are open-weight, meaning they can be downloaded and built upon by researchers for free. Kimi K2 is “the new best open model in the world”, wrote machine-learning researcher Nathan Lambert in a social post.

Nature | 5 min read

Features & opinion

Illustration: Bratislav Milenkovic

Nature contributors’ pick of the best popular science and scholarly books to read now (even if it’s winter — I see you, Southern Hemisphere) include a lyrical exploration of the science of sounds and a deep dive into the reproducibility crisis in biomedical science.

Nature | 10 min read

Biomedical researcher João Conde has seen first-hand what US cuts to science funding means: his cancer-research work in Portugal, done in collaboration with colleagues in the United Kingdom and United States, is now under threat. “The dangers of depending so much on one nation are becoming clear,” he says. Funding and decision-making responsibilities should be spread among more countries, he argues, and all this must be underpinned by shared databases and research-management platforms.

Nature | 5 min read

We have a host of information about ourselves at our fingertips, but often choose to avoid or ignore it. The reasons for this information avoidance fall into three broad categories, explains psychologist Jeremy Foust: protecting a belief, avoiding an undesired action and reducing negative emotions. What’s less clear cut is the extent to which it impacts us. Choosing not to ‘doomscroll’ negative news can benefit our mental health in the short term, but to only engage with what we want to hear can lead us down a rabbit hole of increasingly biased views.

Psyche | 9 min read
articles.reasoning: The article highlights several positive scientific advances including the first observation of a solar system in its earliest formation stage, healthy children born via innovative mitochondrial donation IVF, and progress in AI technology. These developments represent breakthroughs in space science, health, and technology that inspire hope and curiosity about the future.
articles.personality_title: Scientists capture the birth of a solar system for the first time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
For the first time ever, researchers have observed a baby star just as its planets are beginning to form. This discovery was made using a powerful telescope called the Atacama Large Millimeter-submillimeter Array in Chile.

**What happened**
Scientists spotted a young star named HOPS-315 surrounded by material that is blowing away and forming new planets. This star and its surrounding gas and dust give us a rare glimpse into how solar systems like our own begin.

**Impact**
This observation helps us understand the earliest stages of planet formation, improving our knowledge of how stars and planets develop. It also highlights the amazing capabilities of modern telescopes to capture moments we have never seen before.

**What's next step**
Researchers will continue to observe HOPS-315 and similar young stars to learn more about the planet-building process. These studies could reveal the variety of solar systems that exist and how common planets like Earth might be.

**One-sentence takeaway**
For the first time, we’ve seen a solar system being born, opening a new chapter in understanding our cosmic origins.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques capturent pour la première fois la naissance d’un système solaire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Pour la toute première fois, des chercheurs ont observé une étoile bébé au moment où ses planètes commencent à se former. Cette découverte a été réalisée grâce à un puissant télescope appelé l'Atacama Large Millimeter-submillimeter Array au Chili.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les scientifiques ont repéré une jeune étoile nommée HOPS-315 entourée de matière qui s’échappe et forme de nouvelles planètes. Cette étoile et le gaz et la poussière qui l’entourent nous offrent un aperçu rare de la naissance des systèmes solaires.

**Impact**
Cette observation nous aide à mieux comprendre les toutes premières étapes de la formation des planètes, améliorant nos connaissances sur le développement des étoiles et des planètes. Elle montre aussi les capacités incroyables des télescopes modernes à capturer des instants jusqu’ici invisibles.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont continuer à observer HOPS-315 et d’autres jeunes étoiles similaires pour en savoir plus sur le processus de construction des planètes. Ces études pourraient révéler la diversité des systèmes solaires et la fréquence des planètes comme la Terre.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Pour la première fois, nous avons vu la naissance d’un système solaire, ouvrant un nouveau chapitre dans la compréhension de nos origines cosmiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos capturan por primera vez el nacimiento de un sistema solar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Por primera vez, los investigadores han observado una estrella bebé justo cuando sus planetas comienzan a formarse. Este descubrimiento se hizo con un potente telescopio llamado Atacama Large Millimeter-submillimeter Array en Chile.

**Qué pasó**
Los científicos detectaron una joven estrella llamada HOPS-315 rodeada de material que se aleja formando nuevos planetas. Esta estrella y el gas y polvo que la rodean nos ofrecen una mirada rara a cómo comienzan los sistemas solares.

**Impacto**
Esta observación nos ayuda a entender las etapas más tempranas de la formación de planetas, mejorando nuestro conocimiento sobre cómo se desarrollan las estrellas y planetas. También destaca las increíbles capacidades de los telescopios modernos para capturar momentos nunca antes vistos.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores seguirán observando HOPS-315 y otras estrellas jóvenes similares para aprender más sobre el proceso de formación planetaria. Estos estudios podrían revelar la variedad de sistemas solares que existen y qué tan comunes son planetas como la Tierra.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Por primera vez, hemos visto nacer un sistema solar, abriendo un nuevo capítulo en el entendimiento de nuestros orígenes cósmicos.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a glowing young star at the center of a swirling disk of delicate, colorful gas and dust clouds in soft oranges and blues, with gentle streams of bright particles flowing outward symbolizing jets, set against a calm cosmic backdrop of muted dark hues, evoking the birth of a new solar system in a family-friendly, abstract celestial scene.
